Chapter 2 of the Ten Wholesome Courses of Action

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind internally, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does the cultivation of the antidotes to the defiled and undefiled karma of the ten wholesome courses of action proceed?
He sees, hears, and knows, or sees with the divine eye:
For this reason, in the world, the bonds, the wholesome dharmas, are completely extinguished. Namely, the cause of the bonds:
The unwholesome courses of action.

Wholesomeness is the cause of the Buddha, the cause of liberation. What is called wholesome is as follows: Abstaining from killing, embracing all beings in the world, bestowing fearlessness, in the present world, praised by people, with a complexion and faculties that are upright and beautiful, attaining the karma of long life.

If one does not kill, then rÄká¹£asas, kumbhÄá¹‡á¸as, and all evil ghosts that can kill people, as well as other evil people who can kill people, will protect that person in the dark of night. The gods will always follow and observe, protecting them.
When their body perishes and their life ends, they will be reborn in the heavens of the good destinies, and experience wonderful fruits and rewards.
If they diligently make effort and aspire to the three kinds of enlightenment, whether inferior, middling, or superior, they will attain them according to their aspirations:
If that person aspires to the enlightenment of the Å›rÄvakas, they will attain arhatship and enter nirvÄá¹‡a;
If that person aspires to the enlightenment of the pratyekabuddhas, they will attain pratyekabuddhahood;

In the same way, if they aspire to unsurpassed enlightenment, they will attain perfect and complete enlightenment, be endowed with wisdom and practice, be a good guide, understand the world, be a supreme person, a holy one who tames beings, a teacher of gods and humans, a buddha, a world-honored one.
All dharmas have life as their root. People all protect life. Those who do not kill give life.
If one gives life, one gives all happiness;
The foremost giver is the one who gives life.
Thinking like this:
The supreme cause of rebirth in the heavens, the foremost precept, is called giving life.
If one wishes for the supreme happiness of being attached to sensual objects, with non-killing as the cause, that person will then be reborn as Brahma, Mara, or the king of the gods.

If that person wishes to be born as a human superior, they will become a wheel-turning king, possessing the seven treasures and ruling the four continents.ğŸ”½If they wish for a great body as an asura, they will attain a body and become the king of the asuras.
If they wish for a great body as a yaksha, they will become the king of the yakshas.
This non-killing is the greatest seed of the right Dharma.
Practicing in the cycle of birth and death, only non-killing is the refuge and the savior.
Entering the darkness of birth and death, non-killing is the lamp.
Non-killing is called compassion.
Right mindfulness contemplates the goodness of non-killing, and the mind always gives rise to joy.
If one prevents others from killing, others cannot be prevented, then it is practicing abandonment.
That person thus practices the four brahmavihÄras, perfuming their body and mind.
The wholesome roots of not killing are inconceivable, the most true. Whatever kinds of various vows there are, in accordance with the vows, all are attained.
It is just like in the world, a skillful goldsmith, obtaining fine true gold, in accordance with whatever he wishes to make.
That gold thus creates various adornments according to his wishes, whether making vases, or making human images, or making Buddha images.
Thus, thus, for one who does not kill, it is not defective, not pierced, not hollow, not empty. Thus, thus, in accordance with the vows, all are attained.
In accordance with whatever people do not kill like this, then they are close to nirvÄá¹‡a.

That person always practices together with good and virtuous friends. That person is then a wholesome vessel sentient being, well able to gather and take up the blessings and virtues of self and others.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Such a person is a field of merit for the world, and does not go to the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.
This person of good conduct, having accomplished good dharmas, all that is obtained is firm and solid, without fear of kings, thieves, water, or fire, and is used by oneself;
honored among humans, others cannot surpass, because the Dharma is complete.
Therefore, the wise should not kill.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does not stealing lead to good dharmas?
He sees, hears, and knows, or sees with the divine eye:
Those who do not steal emerge from the great net of greed;

In the present, they are trusted by good people, and are trusted by kings and others. Whether in the assembly of kings, the assembly of elders, the assembly of ká¹£atriyas, the assembly of Å›ramaá¹‡as, or the assembly of brÄhmans, all trust them, love and pity them, and believe and accept their words;
All their wealth is solid, not lost or destroyed, and cannot be stolen. They are free from the fears of kings, thieves, water, and fire.
They do not need to make any effort, and wealth comes easily.
Having obtained wealth, they use it according to the Dharma.
They are able to give to those who uphold the precepts, those who practice the path, and all fields of merit. They can provide whatever is needed in the world.
When their body perishes and their life ends, they are reborn in the heavens of the good destinies.
If they wish to transcend the world, they can become Brahma, Mara, Shakra, a wheel-turning king ruling the four continents, complete with the seven treasures. They attain whatever they wish.
If they enjoy upholding the precepts, they attain bodhi as explained above.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does abandoning sexual misconduct lead to attaining its fruits?
He sees, hears, or knows, or sees with the divine eye:
Those who abstain from sexual misconduct will see such phenomena as a result of their wholesome actions and ways.
They will be praised by the virtuous and trusted by all.
They will not have any concerns about other women.
Kings and others will all trust them.
Their wives and concubines will not be able to be taken away by others, and they will be obedient and make offerings without going against their wishes.
Even if there is decline, their wives and concubines will not blame them, and they will be free from jealousy and will not give rise to thoughts of others.
All in the world will see them as mothers, sisters, and so forth, and they will not be reviled by the people.
Those who abstain from sexual misconduct will obtain such a wife.
When their body perishes and their life ends, they will be reborn in the heavens of the good destinies, as explained before.
After that god has fallen, other gods will be born.

If a lustful person is about to fall but has not yet fallen, when other gods are born among those goddesses, those goddesses will immediately follow the other gods in front of him, amusing and laughing with them;
When the gods who are about to fall see the celestial maidens following other celestial sons, amusing themselves and laughing, the noose of jealousy binds them, and they fall into hell.
In this way, the pleasure of sexual misconduct when done much and often is a great loss.
Whoever is able to abstain from sexual misconduct, embracing the path of great goodness, is a vessel for nirvana.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does abandoning false speech, which is the remedy for all unwholesomeness, being included in the category of great goodness, lead to obtaining the fruit of retribution in the present?
He sees, hears, or knows, or with the divine eye he sees:
Those who abstain from false speech, whether seen with the eyes by people in the world or heard by the ears, are all believed;
Even if they are poor and have no wealth, all people in the world make offerings to them as if they were kings.
Just as the moon with light among the stars, so is the light of a truthful person among all people.
Among all treasures, the treasure of truth is supreme.
Among all ships for crossing birth and death, the ship of truth is supreme.
If one wishes to escape all evil deeds, the separation from truth is supreme.
Among all lamps, the lamp of truth is supreme.
Among all good guides in the evil paths, the guide of truth is supreme.

Among all worldly enjoyments, the enjoyment of truth is supreme.ğŸ”½Among all medicinal herbs for curing illnesses, the medicine of truth is supreme.ğŸ”½Among all powerful displays, the power of truth is supreme.
Among all refuges, the refuge of truth is supreme.
Among all knowledge, truth is supreme.
If a person takes up the wealth of truth, then in the world he never engages in evil deeds and does not fall into poverty;
he is close to the heavens and frequently goes and comes;
wherever he is born, he is always a man, born into a superior family, loved by all, and his words are trusted.
Such a person cannot be killed by formless yaká¹£as, piÅ›Äcas, and so forth;
when traveling to other countries, there will be many beds and bedding;
if there is illness, medicine and food will be provided;
whatever one thinks of will be obtained;
one will attain all the supreme pleasures of the world.

When the body perishes and life ends, one will be reborn in the celestial realms of the good destinies, in the place of the longest lifespan, the place of great spiritual powers, and the highest and most excellent place.
If one aspires for the pure and undefiled supreme path, one will attain nirvana, as explained above.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with internal mind, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does one, by refraining from the evil deed of divisive speech, attain the karmic fruits in the present and future through the practice of the good path of action?
He sees, hears, or knows, or sees with the divine eye:

Those who abandon divisive speech will, in the present life, experience the fruits of their actions. Their friends, relatives, brothers, wives, children, servants, and workers will all be steadfast and no one will be able to break them apart. Kings, enemies, and evil brothers will not be able to cause division;
even if they have no wealth, they will not abandon them;
even if they encounter famine or travel through wilderness, mountains, or dangerous places, they will not abandon them, but always enjoy being with them;
if others use various means to speak divisive words, they will not listen even if they hear them;
the king will have a steadfast good heart towards them;
water, thieves, swords, and enemies will not be able to frighten them, because they have abandoned the unwholesome action of divisive speech.
Those who abandon divisive speech in this way will, when their body perishes and their life ends, be born in the heavens of the good destinies.
Among the heavenly multitudes, they will be surrounded by many heavenly maidens, who will always follow them, love them, and delight them.
The bodies of those celestial maidens are adorned with wonderful garlands, scattered incense, and ointments, surpassing the celestial maidens of the first heaven, always giving rise to joy.
If one abandons divisive speech and aspires for purity and freedom from outflows, then one will attain the path of meditation free from outflows and reach nirvana, as explained above.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does one abandon harsh speech, an unwholesome karmic path, in the present world and attain the karmic retribution in the present life?
Where will one be reborn in the future?
He sees, hears, and knows, or sees with the divine eye:
Abandoning harsh speech, one sees excellent and wonderful forms, is trusted by people, and everyone in the world enjoys associating with him;
Smooth speech and soft speech comfort everyone and do not cause fear;
Everyone in the world, even from afar, goes to be near him;
He has many good friends;
Even if he has no wealth, he can make everyone respect him like a slave in an instant;
If one has been afflicted by evil karma from past lives, people will not abandon them;
all wealth and possessions will be easily obtained;
this person will have no enemies, no fear of kings, water, knives, fire, and so forth.
When the body perishes and life ends, they will be reborn in the celestial realms of the good destinies.
Having been born there, they will attain speech that is smooth, beneficial, concise, and in accord with the cause, and will attain great spiritual powers and an excellent form.
If they wish to attain liberation, enjoy the bliss of meditation, and practice the uncontaminated Dharma, they will attain the three kinds of enlightenment, as explained above.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does one abandon frivolous speech, which is an unwholesome karmic path in the world, and attain the karmic rewards of wholesome actions in the present life?
Where will they be reborn in the future?
He sees, hears, and knows, or sees with the divine eye:

Abandoning frivolous speech, in this very life, they will be respected by the world, remembered by good people, and their words before and after will not contradict each other. All worldly people will love their speech, and no one will intimidate them or seek their faults;
Good speech and right speech are respected by the world;
Little speech and soft speech are easy for others to understand;
Speech in accord with the Dharma, not coarse speech, and speech with deep causes all have principles and do not contradict the Dharma;
All worldly people who see them respect them;
Their wealth and treasures are all solid and their enjoyment is satisfactory;
To those without virtue, they speak of having merit, and to those without merit, they speak of their merits.
When their body perishes and their life ends, they will be reborn in the heavens of the good destinies.
Having been born there, the gods respect and love them. They have great spiritual powers and experience heavenly wealth and bliss, which cannot be fully described.
If one wishes for pure, immaculate dhyÄna bliss, one will attain the three kinds of enlightenment as one wishes, as explained before.
Thus, these three kinds of unwholesome bodily actions and these four kinds of unwholesome verbal actions should be gradually abandoned until nirvÄá¹‡a.
The causes of those wholesome actions are praised by the world, and one will next be reborn in the heavens and later attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
Those bodily and verbal actions are the true results of karma. Practitioners contemplate internally, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing in this way, and thus know and see the truth.
Moreover, practitioners contemplate internally, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: What is the practice of the wholesome path of mental action?
They see, hear, or know, or see with the divine eye:
Mental actions are of three kinds:
greed, ill-will, and wrong views. The wholesome antidotes bring happiness in the present life, and after the body perishes and life ends, one is reborn in the heavens, the realm of the devas.
If one is disgusted with birth and death, one enters the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind of inner reflection, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does one, by abandoning unwholesome actions of greed, attain the fruits of wholesome actions?
He sees, hears, and knows, or sees with the divine eye:

Those who are free from greed, in the present world, will have abundant wealth and precious treasures, which no one can encroach upon. Even kings and their equals will not give rise to thoughts [of stealing], let alone engage in theft or robbery.
If there are circumstances where one loses wealth and other people obtain it, they will be like relatives and return it to them;
That person will always be wealthy, with wealth and possessions never leaving, and will always be free from being harmed by others.
When the body perishes and life ends, they will be reborn in the celestial realms of the good destinies.
Once born there, the devas and asuras fight each other, but those asuras are invincible, cannot be killed, cannot be frightened by others, and are not afraid of others;
all the devas love them and feel compassion for them;
they have food of sound, touch, form, taste, and smell that is indescribably delightful.

If they wish for the pure, bright, undefiled dhyÄna concentrations, the path and fruition, and the three kinds of enlightenment of the world, they will attain them according to their wishes, as explained above.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with inner correct thought, observing in accordance with the true Dharma: How does one, by abandoning unwholesome actions of anger, attain the fruits of wholesome actions?
He sees, hears, or knows, or with the divine eye sees: As for those who abandon anger, in their present lives, the karmic fruits of their actions are:
abundant wealth and great riches;
all love and cherish them, and feel compassion for them;
in the most dangerous and fearful places, no one can take advantage of them;
fears of kings, thieves, falling off cliffs, water, fire, flattery, and so forth, immeasurable fears, fears of narrow places, and so forth, are all completely eliminated;
all worldly people love and cherish him the most, even evil people give rise to love and affection, and all good people love and cherish him like a son or brother.

When the body perishes and life ends, he is reborn in the heavens of the good destinies, attains great spiritual powers, attains a supreme and wonderful body, and always obtains all lovable wonderful sounds, touches, tastes, smells, and forms, which he uses as he wishes;

there are joyful gardens, wonderfully marvelous tree groves, jeweled palanquins, surrounded by celestial maidens in the great forest, and no other gods can frighten him by disturbing his body, speech, or mind;
hundreds of thousands of celestial sons pity him in their hearts, are close to him, and love him, and the king of the gods, Indra, loves and pities him;
When the gods and asuras fight, they do not become timid or fearful.

If one wishes to escape from the defilements and impurities, and attain the supramundane path, then when one falls from the heavens and is reborn among humans, one becomes a wheel-turning king, going back and forth through countless lifetimes, ruling the four continents with the seven treasures.
The so-called female treasure:
The body of that female treasure emits the fragrance of sandalwood, and her mouth always emits the fragrance of blue lotus flowers. Her touch is soft and fine, like the touch of a kalaviá¹…ka bird.
A kalaviá¹…ka is a bird on an island in the ocean.
The power of that touch, if it touches a person's body, eliminates fatigue, and one is free from hunger, thirst, worry, sorrow, suffering, and distress;
the people on that island obtain the power of that touch.
The female treasure is also like this. If the wheel-turning king sees or touches her, he experiences bliss;
when it is cold, her body is warm, and when it is hot, she is cool and refreshing. Such a power of touch is not obtained by other people;
The power of the good karma of being free from anger and following the right path;
All men who see this precious woman will have good discrimination, like a mother or sister, and will be single-minded towards the king;
They will respect the king, focus their minds on the king, and always engage in joyful practices;
They will be free from the five kinds of faults of women, namely, unchastity, engaging in sexual acts with other men, jealousy, evil greed, and living on their own after the husband's death.
This precious woman also has five kinds of merits, namely, following her husband's intentions, giving birth to many sons, not being of a low caste, delighting in good people, and not being jealous.
When her husband entertains other women, she does not become jealous.
She also has three kinds of great and excellent merits of a woman, namely, not speaking much;
not having deviant views;
not enjoying sounds, touches, tastes, smells, etc. when her husband is not present, and her mind being unmoved.
Due to these causes and conditions, when the body perishes and life ends, one is then reborn in the celestial realms of the good destinies.
Such a supreme and wonderful female treasure's food is only obtained by a wheel-turning king.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does one abandon the mind of anger with many defilements and obtain the karmic retribution of good karma as a wheel-turning king?
He sees, hears, and knows, or sees with the divine eye:
Abandoning the evil and unwholesome karma of anger towards others, with the remaining good karma, one obtains the second treasure's food of a wheel-turning king, namely the jewel treasure.

This has eight kinds of virtues: In the darkness of the night, it produces good light, like the full autumn moon free from clouds. In this way, the jewel treasure can illuminate the darkness with light, pervading a hundred yojanas. Moreover, during the day when the sun's heat is unbearable, it emits cool light to remove the heat and bring coolness;
This is the first virtue of the jewel treasure.

Furthermore, the second merit of the jewel is that if one travels through a wilderness with no water and the troops are thirsty, it can cause many streams of pure water with eight qualities to flow out, eliminating all thirst;
this is the second merit of the jewel.
Furthermore, the third merit of the jewel is that if the wheel-turning king recollects water, the jewel will flow according to the king's intention;
this is the third merit of the jewel.
Furthermore, the fourth merit of the jewel is that the jewel has eight facets, and each facet emits various colors:
blue, yellow, red, white, purple, and crystal colors;
this is the fourth merit of the jewel.

Furthermore, the fifth merit of the jewel is that the power of the jewel eliminates illness within a hundred yojanas, the mind becomes upright, and all desires are in accordance with one's karma, without failure to receive their fruits;
this is the fifth merit of the jewel.
Moreover, the sixth merit of the jewel is that by the power of that jewel, it causes the evil dragons not to bring down evil rains;
such is the sixth merit of that jewel.

Moreover, the seventh merit of the jewel is that in places without water, on steep cliffs and in the wilderness without trees or grass, that jewel can cause many trees, ponds, lotus flowers, and green grass to be fully provided;
such is the seventh merit of that jewel.
Moreover, the eighth merit of the jewel is that by the power of the jewel, no one dies an untimely death, and it causes animals not to kill each other or be hateful toward each other.
Those who are hateful toward each other are snakes, rats, and wolves.
Such are the eight kinds of supreme great merits that are fully endowed and associated with each other.

The karmic rewards obtained from the wholesome actions of the wheel-turning king's freedom from anger are that he is fully endowed with a thousand sons, all of whom are brave and strong, foremost among men, with excellent physical appearances that can crush the armies of others, and they follow the wheel-turning king's mind and intentions.
They are upright and delightful, like righteous good people, following the practice of the Dharma, similar to the wheel-turning king's lineage;
in all the villages and great assemblies, they are all respected and loved, praising their mental practices.

Furthermore, the practitioner, with inner focused mind, contemplates in accordance with the true Dharma and observes the practice of the Dharma: How does one, by practicing the wholesome action of freedom from anger, obtain the third wheel treasure of the wheel-turning king that appears in the world?
He sees, hears, or knows this, or sees it with the divine eye:
That wheel treasure has five merits that are fully possessed.
Namely, it has a thousand spokes:
Its body is all JambÅ«nada gold, five yojanas wide, like a second sun illuminating the world;
Such is the first merit of the wheel treasure.
Moreover, the second merit of the wheel treasure is that it moves unimpeded, flying through the sky and able to travel a hundred thousand yojanas in a single day.

Moreover, the third merit of the wheel treasure is that it follows the king's thoughts and wishes. If he wishes to travel to any place, whether to GodÄnÄ«ya, PÅ«rvavideha, Uttarakuru, or the abode of the Four Heavenly Kings, the thousand-spoked wheel flies through the sky to those places.
By the power of the wheel treasure, it can cause the four armies of elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry to all follow and fly through the sky together.
Moreover, the fourth merit of the wheel treasure is that if there are those who do not submit to the wheel-turning king, that golden wheel will follow the king and be able to subdue them.

Moreover, the fifth merit of the wheel treasure is that there is no enemy that can rival that golden wheel. If kings and others see it, they will immediately submit. It is all due to the power of the Dharma. Because the wheel-turning king follows it, he is able to do so.
Thus, this wheel treasure is endowed with five kinds of merits and characteristics.
Thus have I explained the third great treasure.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with inner thoughts, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does one, by practicing the good karma of abandoning anger, obtain the fourth elephant treasure of the wheel-turning king that appears in the world?
He sees, hears, or knows this, or sees it with the divine eye:

This wheel-turning king practices the Dharma, in accordance with the practice of the Dharma, obtains a well-tamed elephant, the foremost in taming, able to conquer other cities, with seven parts touching the ground, namely the four feet, tail, head, and tusks, these seven parts all touch the ground.

If there are these seven characteristics, that elephant has great strength, a thousand times stronger than other weak elephants, its hair is soft, its color is white like snow, like Indra's elephant Airavata;
The other elephants, smelling its scent, immediately submit and dare not look directly at it;
They can fight in three places, namely water, on land, and in the sky;
They can travel very quickly, and in one day can circle JambudvÄ«pa three times.
That elephant is well-trained, and if led by a single thread tied to its neck, if the wheel-turning king rides it, then the elephant is well-behaved and in accord with the king's mind;

If the wheel-turning king wishes to go somewhere, then he need not give instructions, and the elephant will quickly arrive at that place. It moves evenly and upright, without shaking or swaying, its steps are deliberate, its body does not move or sway, it lifts its feet in sequence, does not prance or gallop, and also does not use force in anger. It performs various good actions;
Even small children see it without fear;
In the four avenues of the city, or on top of multi-story buildings, when it goes to those places, women can touch it, and can even rub it with their hands;
When fighting in battle, it is very brave and fierce, but when moving, it is well-behaved and does not break free from the reins.

In this way, the great elephant treasure of the wheel-turning king is obtained from the seeds of practicing one of the ten wholesome paths of action among the wheel-turning king's ten wholesome paths of action. How much more so for fully and perfectly practicing the ten wholesome paths of action and obtaining it.
In this way, one who practices in accordance with the Dharma and cultivates the Dharma sees with the heavenly eye that the wheel-turning king's fourth elephant treasure.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind in accordance with the true Dharma and observes the practice of the Dharma: How does the wheel-turning king obtain the horse treasure?
What merits and virtues does the horse treasure have that are in accord with it?
He sees, hears, and knows, or sees with the heavenly eye:

The horse treasure has the pure color of a goose or a bandhuka flower. Its entire body is adorned with the marks of heavenly whorls and so forth. It has the foremost marks, size, color, shape, and so forth, and is in accord with all the marks. It is extremely well-trained;
In one day, it can circle JambudvÄ«pa three times without tiring.
Thus the wheel-turning king obtains this fifth meritorious horse treasure.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with inner thoughts, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does the wheel-turning king obtain the treasure of the general?
He sees, hears, and knows, or sees with the divine eye:
What are the merits of that treasure of the general?
Namely, the wheel-turning king recollects and thinks, without waiting for instructions, he knows the king's thoughts and is able to accomplish all that the king needs;
He stays far away from what is not the Dharma and practices in accordance with the true Dharma;
When the time and place require it, he accomplishes what the king intends without hardship or trouble, taking it in accordance with the true Dharma;
Whatever the king thinks of and needs, everything he does does not go against the meaning of the Dharma, and he is able to accomplish everything that needs to be done within the king's realm.

Thus the wheel-turning king, apart from the wholesome karma of anger, obtains the treasure of the general, and always practices the ten wholesome courses of action, benefiting all sentient beings in the world, just like parents.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does the wheel-turning king obtain the seventh great minister of the treasury, the wealthy elder treasure?
What are the merits of that elder treasure?
He sees, hears, and knows, or sees with the divine eye:
The great minister of the treasury treasure belongs to the wheel-turning king. What are the merits?

He can fill all pits, ravines, deep mountains, valleys, dangerous cliffs, and uneven places with various wonderful treasures such as vajra, indranÄ«la gems, maá¹‡i pearls, and muÅ›Äragalva, without the king's command and without the treasures being exhausted, let alone gold and silver.
This elder treasure is the foremost in comparison, not deceiving, not flattering, not causing distress to others, and all who see him love him with coolness.
This is the wheel-turning king's wealthy elder treasure.
Thus, the wheel-turning king, endowed with the seven treasures and ruling the four continents, can sit together with the dragon-devas and the thirty-three devas.
There are two heavenly realms:
the heaven of the four heavenly kings and the heaven of the thirty-three.
The king of the thirty-three devas shares his seat with the wheel-turning king.
Thus, endowed with these seven kinds of wondrous treasures, one becomes a wheel-turning king.

Moreover, there are seven other similar treasures, inferior to the previous seven treasures, namely the sword treasure, the hide treasure, the bed treasure, the forest treasure, the palace treasure, the robe treasure, and the footwear treasure.
What are the merits of the sword treasure similar to that of the wheel-turning king?
If there are countries that rise up in rebellion, this sword treasure will swiftly go there. All countries will submit upon seeing the sword, without a single person being killed.
This sword treasure has such merits:
without punishment or killing, all countries will naturally submit.
This is the merit of the first sword treasure.
How does the wheel-turning king obtain the second treasure similar to skin?
What are the merits of that second treasure?
That skin treasure is born in the ocean;
After it is born, merchants obtain it and bring it to the king.
The merits of that treasure are:

It is five yojanas wide and ten yojanas long, the skin of a sea dragon, not rotten by water or rain, not moved by wind, not burned by fire, able to ward off cold and heat, able to warm in cold times and cool in hot times;

Wherever the wheel-turning king goes - following the king's army, led by the lord of the army treasure - it can serve as a house, able to accommodate the king and his army, each separated, wives and husbands not mixed, not seeing each other;
Its color is pure white, like the light of the sun.
Such are the merits of the second skin treasure.
How does the wheel-turning king obtain the third treasure similar to a bed?
What are the merits of that third treasure?
As for that bed treasure, it is soft and smooth, and when one sits on it, it sinks in, and when one stands up, it returns to level.

From that bed emerges a small meditation hut. Even if a woman has extremely lustful thoughts towards the king, when she sees that bed treasure, her mind becomes free from desire.

It is woven tightly with fine threads, supremely soft, and not soiled by dirt. When the king puts it on, he is free from cold, heat, hunger, thirst, emaciation, fatigue, and exhaustion. Fire cannot burn it and a knife cannot cut it.
